question: A 50-year-old woman has had a high fever over the past day. On physical examination she has papilledema. The gross appearance of her disease process is shown here. Which of the following laboratory test results is she most likely to have? <image 1>
options: ['Erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 50 mm/hr', 'Serum lipase of 449 U/L', 'Total serum complement of 45 mg/dL', 'Serum carcinoembryonic antigen of 10 ng/mL', 'Serum alanine aminotransferase of 123 U/L', 'Proteinuria']
description: The image shows a close-up view of a brain with a highly inflamed and swollen appearance. The surface of the brain exhibits significant edema, characterized by a puffy and swollen texture. The gyri (ridges) and sulci (grooves) are less distinct than normal, indicating increased pressure within the brain. The overall color of the brain tissue appears reddish-brown, suggesting inflammation or hemorrhage. The presence of prominent blood vessels on the surface further indicates vascular involvement in the pathological process. This appearance is consistent with conditions such as meningitis or encephalitis, which can cause severe inflammation and swelling of the brain tissues.
